ygData.subject: Re: Online Soft Computing Conference
ygData.msgSnippet: Ian, I built a home-brew version of GEP in Delphi without ever seeing any stunning results. IIRC, the original paper (from which I built my interpretation) was

Ian, 

I built a home-brew version of GEP in Delphi without ever seeing any
stunning results. IIRC, the original paper (from which I built my
interpretation) was a dissertation. Candida Ferreira, the author, is
now something like Chief Scientist at GEPSoft, which markets a
commercial implementation of GEP. I seem to have noticed her rather
stridently promoting/defending her "baby" when I've visited GP groups
from time to time... 

As seems to happen all too often, objectivity goes out the window when
commercial concerns appear.

I am mildly curious about the idea of using "mini-GEPs" to evolve
novel activation functions, though...

Mike


--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Ian Badcoe <ian_badcoe@y...> wrote:
> Personally I don't rate GEP.  It is an interesting idea but not clearly 
> thought through.  NEAT OTOH is a great advance on several fronts...
> 
> At 16:25 21/09/2004 +0000, you wrote:
> 
> >Ian, I have been asked about how GEP compares to NEAT before so I
> >put a question in the NEAT FAQ:
> >
> >"Is NEAT similar to the GEP method of Genetic Programming?"
> >
> >at: http://www.cs.utexas.edu/users/kstanley/neat.html
> >
> >This is the first time I've heard of it being used for NN's.
> >Although it's probably an advance for GP, it lacks several useful
> >properties of NEAT.  Of course, I have not read the present paper,
> >so my understanding is based on earlier work.
> >
> >ken
> >
> >--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Ian Badcoe <ian_badcoe@y...> wrote:
> > > Hi,
> > >       One of the contributors on the GP mailing list mentioned
> >this conference:
> > >
> > > http://www.cs.nmt.edu/~wsc9/
> > >
> > >       As far as I can tell it is free and completely online.
> >Also, the paper
> > > she submitted (which I did not read yet) is on using GEP (a
> >variant of GP)
> > > to create neural nets.
> > >
> > > -------------
> > >
> > > Ferreira, C., Designing Neural Networks Using Gene Expression
> >Programming.
> > > 9th Online World Conference on Soft Computing in Industrial
> >Applications,
> > > September 20 - October 8, 2004.
> > >
> > > ABSTRACT:
> > > An artificial neural network with all its elements is a rather
> >complex
> > > structure, not easily constructed and/or trained to perform a
> >particular
> > > task. Consequently, several researchers used Genetic Algorithms to
> >evolve
> > > partial aspects of neural networks, such as the weights, the
> >thresholds, and
> > > the network architecture. Indeed, over the last decade many
> >systems have
> > > been developed that perform total network induction. In this work
> >it is
> > > shown how the chromosomes of Gene Expression Programming can be
> >modified so
> > > that a complete neural network, including the architecture, the
> >weights and
> > > thresholds, could be totally encoded in a linear chromosome. It is
> >also
> > > shown how this chromosomal organization allows the
> >training/adaptation of
> > > the network using the evolutionary mechanisms of selection and
> >modification,
> > > thus providing an approach to the automatic design of neural
> >networks. The
> > > workings and performance of this new algorithm are tested on the
> > > 6-multiplexer and on the classical exclusive-or problems.
> > >
> > > ------------------
> > >
> > >       Does that sound at all familiar?
> > >
> > >       Ian
> > >
